subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Is there a way to nasalize a vowel? and to express certain consonants?
msgSnippet: ... Actually the QS LL signifies the *Welsh* _ll_, that is a voiceless fricative _l_!  The jocular advice for pronouncing Welsh _pwll_ is to pronounce
messageBody:
cossyrosario wrote:
> Another signifies
> ll as in the Spanish llama, which, I take it, is like the gl in the
> Italian article gli. (The Portuguese have a similar sound in lhe.)

Actually the QS "LL" signifies the *Welsh* _ll_, that is a voiceless
fricative _l_! The jocular advice for pronouncing Welsh _pwll_ is to
pronounce English _push_ and _pull_ simultaneously! :) That this is
an extremely difficult sound for English speakers is shown by such
Anglicizations as _Floyd_ for Welsh _Llwyd_. If you know Spanish you
can substitute _jl_ ("Jlúid").

>
> How would we express the ch of loch and the ll of llama in Shavian?

In QS I would use Low+You as the closest approximation.

>
> Also, I don't find anything either in Quikscript or in Shavian for the
> pure nasal as in "bon jour". In "bon" the o is nasalized, thus the n
> is not a consonant. The Shavian n stands for the consonant n as in
> bonfire.
>
> The fact is that we do use Fremch words in English. "Elan" comes to
> mind as an example, but there should obviously be other examples too.
> How would one write "elan" in Shavian?

I would put an Ing after the vowel. There is nothing in French it can
be confused with.

> Cossy



--

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch at melroch dot se

Solitudinem faciunt pacem appellant!
(Tacitus)
